utterances: Is there any downside to this?
The only downside that I can tell you is that unfortunately, some of the - I was talking to someone the other day - it cost you $35 to park your car in South Beach.
(SOUNDBITE OF LAUGHTER)
That's Oliver Ruiz.
He's managing broker of Fortune International Realty in Florida.
Thank you so much for talking to us today.
Oh, my pleasure.
Reporter Jennifer Sharpe recently caught up with Captain Hook at her L.A.
apartment with a lap full of granny squares.
Captain Hook is taking street art back to the old school.
This is crochet on a statue.
This could be happening in 1725.
Most street artists travel with spray paint or markers.
Captain Hook, as she's asked me to call her for this story, works with a crochet needle and yarn.
Her walls are public fixtures like the bronze bear statue in L.A.'s Griffith Park that stands zombie-like with its paws out.
I met up with her as she embarked on what would become the bear's tenth outfit, its St. Patrick's Day attire.
I can't make the same thing over and over.
I made a vest, and I made some shorts, then I made some different shorts.
Then I made some lederhosen.
And now, I think I'm going for the full body.
Like a body glove?
Yeah, a body glove in four shades of green.
It's ambitious, but she's confident.
You see, Captain Hook grew up on a '70s commune, where she was part of the an all-girl needlepoint workforce.
You always had to be making something.
So in the houses that I grew up in, there's blankets and embroidered dresses and pillows covered in needlework.
I mean, we rocked it, we were good.
But when I arrived at her apartment the afternoon of the installation, she was crocheting frantically.
I've been hysterical basically.
I woke up at six this morning, and I made most of these squares.
And is this still going to be a full body glove?
No, it's going to be a shrug with a hood.
It's going to be sleeves and a back and then a hood.
When you sew it down, it actually looks good.
This is it.
This is it.
Okay, we got it.
We got it.
The time to vandalize the bear has finally arrived.
Yeah, and it's all pulled down, yeah...
Genius.
But in the half hour they struggle with the bear's hood, none of the people exercising, lounging in the grass, or walking their dogs seem to even notice.
Vanessa, would you agree with me that it's just weird?
I don't know why it doesn't satisfy me in the way that others have.
(SOUNDBITE OF CAR HORN)
Thanks.
That was that support, right?
That was support, yeah.
Who took it down?
That wasn't me on that one.
No, that wasn't me.
As it turns out, the man ultimately responsible for the bear, Marshal Barrena, the park's senior gardener, is a fan.
It just, you know, puts a little spring in your step the next morning when you see something like that.
A little spring in your step?
Yeah, right, exactly.
Hey, that's cool, you know.
If, in a place of 10 million people, Captain Hook has succeeded in making one gardener and a few passers-by stop and laugh, she feels she's reached her goal.
And she contemplates moving on.
I was just looking the other day, and there's a bust of Valentino that I think would look really great with a scarf.
Because one of the great things about Los Angeles is that there's always something else out there just begging for a pair of crocheted lederhosen.
I saw there's a dolphin in Santa Monica somewhere that is actually standing much like the bear, fins out.
When I saw that, I was like: Dude, your days are numbered.
For NPR News, I'm Jennifer Sharpe.
And one final note.
Over the weekend, someone outfitted the Griffith Park bear statue with Easter attire, complete with bunny ears.
You've got to see this for yourself.
Go to npr.org.
(SOUNDBITE OF MUSIC)
You're listening to ALL THINGS CONSIDERED from NPR News.
California continues to wrestle with a multibillion dollar budget gap.
To help close it, Governor Arnold Schwarzenegger is proposing to raise taxes on a number of services, among them veterinary care.
Gloria Hillard reports that the proposed tax is not going down well with pet owners.
(Soundbite of dog barking)
I would have never put the two together, you know.
When you Google `Hula-Hooping,' you know, `The String Cheese Incident' comes up.
This is String Cheese's road manager, Chewy Smith.
He says he won't see hooping at every show, but that the band's contract stipulates every venue must allow Hula-Hoops inside.
Anytime during the summer when we're playing these outdoor festivals, I mean, there's 50, 60 people in the back totally grooving with Hula-Hoops on.
It's a riot to sit there and watch.
I mean, there's professional hoopers at this point.
I'm sorry.
Take a moment to consider those two words together: `professional hoopers.'
And they are.
I mean, they have business cards that say, `So-and-So, professional hooper for parties,' like sort of Cirque du Soleil type thing, as well, you know.
There are even hoop troupes, like a group called Groove Hoops in New York that actually performed with String Cheese this past summer.

I heard one Groove Hooper was going to be at the Portland, Maine, show--or as String Cheese fans would call it, `The Incident'--so I arranged to meet her at a pre-Incident party down the street from the theater.
(Soundbite of laughter)
Hi.
